       AN  ACT  to  amend  the education law, in relation to establishment of a
         facilitator center for private and parochial schools

         THE PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, REPRESENTED IN SENATE AND  ASSEM-
       BLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS:

    1    Section 1. The education law is amended by adding a new section 115 to
    2  read as follows:
    3    S 115. FACILITATOR CENTER FOR PRIVATE AND PAROCHIAL SCHOOLS.  1. THERE
    4  IS  HEREBY  ESTABLISHED THE FACILITATOR CENTER FOR PRIVATE AND PAROCHIAL
    5  SCHOOLS TO SUPPORT THE ACTIVITIES OF INDEPENDENT AND  RELIGIOUS  SCHOOLS
    6  IN  THE STATE; TO PROMOTE, FOSTER, AND ENCOURAGE ACADEMIC EXCELLENCE AND
    7  SCHOLASTIC ACHIEVEMENT IN SUCH SCHOOLS; TO RECEIVE  ALLOCATIONS  OF  AID
    8  FROM  THE FEDERAL, STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS AND SUBDIVISIONS THEREOF;
    9  TO ADMINISTER AND EXPEND SUCH ALLOCATIONS ON BEHALF OF SUCH  SCHOOLS  IN
   10  ACCORDANCE  WITH THE LAWS, RULES AND/OR REGULATIONS GOVERNING SUCH ALLO-
   11  CATIONS.
   12    2. THE COMMISSIONER SHALL, UPON THE REQUEST OF ONE OR MORE PRIVATE AND
   13  PAROCHIAL SCHOOLS, REALLOCATE TO THE FACILITATOR  CENTER  SUCH  FEDERAL,
   14  STATE OR LOCAL EDUCATION FUNDS AS HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED BY SUCH SCHOOL OR
   15  SCHOOLS  IN  ORDER  THAT  SUCH  FUNDS BE ADMINISTERED BY THE FACILITATOR
   16  CENTER. THE ADMINISTRATIVE CHARGES  OF  THE  FACILITATOR  CENTER,  WHICH
   17  SHALL BE DEDUCTED FROM SUCH FEDERAL, STATE AND/OR LOCAL EDUCATION FUNDS,
   18  SHALL BE ESTABLISHED AND ADJUSTED ACCORDING TO A MEMORANDUM OF AGREEMENT
   19  BETWEEN THE COMMISSIONER, THE CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER OF THE FACILITATOR
   20  CENTER AND A REPRESENTATIVE OF SUCH SCHOOL OR SCHOOLS.
   21    3.  THE COMMISSIONER SHALL PROMULGATE ANY RULE OR REGULATION NECESSARY
   22  TO CARRY OUT THE PROVISIONS OF THIS SECTION.
   23    S 2. This act shall take effect immediately.

        EXPLANATION--Matter in ITALICS (underscored) is new; matter in brackets
                             [ ] is old law to be omitted.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S1584

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the education law, in relation to establishment of a
facilitator center for private and parochial schools

PURPOSE:
To establish a mechanism to more efficiently and effectively
administer federal, state and local education funds intended to
benefit the students and teachers in the state's independent and
religious schools and to promote, foster and encourage academic
excellence and scholastic achievement in such schools.

SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:
Section one establishes the Facilitator Center for Independent and
Religious Schools as a means by which such schools may choose to have
their respective federal, state, and/or local education funds
administered.

Section two establishes an immediate effective date

JUSTIFICATION:
A number of state and federal education funding programs are designed
to benefit all children and teachers regardless of whether they are
in public or independent/religious schools. These include 12 of the
16 title programs under the federal Elementary and Secondary
Education Act (ESEA) as well as the state's several instructional
material aid programs.

In most cases, however, these funds, including the funds intended to
benefit children and teachers in independent and religious schools,
must be administered in public schools, which further burdens public
school administrators with programs designed to benefit children for
which they have no direct responsibility. Moreover, independent and
religious school
administrators often find it difficult to access such funds in an
efficient, effective and timely manner.

The Regional Facilitator Center for Nonpublic Schools was established
in the early 1980s to serve independent and religious schools
throughout the state. In addition to other services, the Facilitator
Center has served as a "third party administrator" for a number of
the federal education title program funds on behalf of groups of
religious and independent schools.

Codifying the Facilitator Center in state law will enable the
religious and independent schools to choose to have their state
education funding programs administered by the Facilitator Center.
This will provide significant administrative relief for public school
districts currently required to administer such programs and will
enable religious and independent school administrators to access
these programs more effectively and efficiently for their students
and teachers.

LEGISLATIVE HISTORY:


S.5415 from 2009 - Referred to Education Committee

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
None to the state or public school districts.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
Immediately.
